{{Infobox political party |country = Wales |name = Wales Green Party |native_name = Plaid Werdd Cymru |colorcode = {{Green Party of England and Wales/meta/color}} |party_logo = |leader = [[Jake Griffiths]] |chairman = |foundation = 1973 |ideology = [[Green politics]] |position = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] |international = [[Global Greens]] |european = [[European Green Party]] |europarl = [[The GreensâEuropean Free Alliance]] |colours = [[Green]] |headquarters = [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]] |website = [http://wales.greenparty.org.uk/index.php?id=3325 http://wales.greenparty.org.uk/] }} {{Green politics sidebar |expanded=all}} The '''Wales Green Party''' ('''WGP'''; {{lang-cy|Plaid Werdd Cymru}}) is a semi-[[Autonomous entity|autonomous]] [[political party]] within the [[Green Party of England and Wales]] (GPEW). It covers [[Wales]], and is the only regional party with autonomous status within the GPEW.
The WGP fights [[elections]] for the [[National Assembly for Wales]] (as well as at the [[Local government in the United Kingdom|local]], [[UK Parliament|UK]] and [[European Parliament|European]] level) and has its own newsletters, membership list, [[Annual General Meeting|AGM]]s and [[manifesto]]. Members of the WGP are automatically members of the GPEW.
==Leadership== The current Leader is [[Jake Griffiths]]. Wales is represented internally within the GPEW by [[John Matthews]] on the [[Green Party of England and Wales#Regional Council|Green Party Regional Council]] (GPRC). Both sets of positions are directly elected by postal ballot.
Other officer positions within WGP (elected at AGM) are as follows: *General Secretary *Membership Secretary *Treasurer *Press Officer *Local Party Development Officer *Campaigns Coordinator *Green Wales Editor *Conferences Coordinator *Fund-raising Officer *Web Officer
Wales-wide decisions are taken by the Wales Green Party Council made up of the spokespeople, the officers listed above and a representative from each local party.
==History== ===1992=== In [[United Kingdom general election, 1992|1992]], an electoral alliance culminated in Plaid Cymru's [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Cynog Dafis]] being endorsed by the local Green Party in [[Ceredigion (UK Parliament constituency)|Ceredigion]]. The agreement broke down by 1995.<ref>[http://www.llgc.org.uk/Ymgyrchu/Pleidleisio/lleiafrifol/Werdd/index-e.htm Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru - National Library of Wales : Error<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.llgc.org.uk/gwyb/gwyb_s_datganiad051028.htm Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru - National Library of Wales : Error<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.greens.org/s-r/13/13-07.html S/R 13: How Green Was My Party?<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===2003=== In the [[National Assembly for Wales election, 2003|May 2003 election]] to the [[National Assembly for Wales]], the party fielded a list of candidates for each of the [[National Assembly for Wales constituencies and electoral regions#Electoral regions|top-up regions]] but no candidates for the [[National Assembly for Wales constituencies and electoral regions#Constituencies|constituencies]]. The party failed to win any seats, coming closest in South Wales West with 4.8% of the vote.
===2004=== In the [[UK elections, 2004|2004 elections]], the Welsh party failed to gain any seats in the [[European Parliament]] (with 3.6% of [[European Parliament Election, 2004 (UK)#Wales|the vote for the four Welsh seats]]) and lost their only [[county council]] seat (of [[Klaus Armstrong-Braun]] in [[Flintshire]]).

===2009=== In the [[European Parliament election, 2009 (United Kingdom)]], the Welsh party failed to gain any seats in the [[European Parliament]], but increased the vote to 5.6% for the four Welsh seats).
===2011=== The Wales Green Party fielded candidates in all 5 [[National Assembly for Wales constituencies and electoral regions#Electoral regions|top-up regions]] for the [[National Assembly for Wales election, 2011]]. There were both candidates fielded in [[National Assembly for Wales constituencies and electoral regions#Electoral regions|top-up regions]] and one candidate fielded for the [[National Assembly for Wales constituencies and electoral regions#Constituencies|constituencies]].
